bioghist.p: The Phebe Anna Thorne Model School of Bryn Mawr College was founded in 1910; school facilities opened in 1913. Educating students ages 10 and older, the school was cited by John Dewey of Columbia University as one of the "schools of tomorrow," but closed in 1931. In 1952, Katharine Elizabeth McBride, then president of Bryn Mawr, reopened it as a laboratory nursery school for the Graduate Department of Education. The school promotes active participation of parents in play-tutoring and advanced methods of child development.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of records related to the two incarnations of the Phebe Anna Thorne School. Materials include correspondence, student records, curricula and pedagogical guides, publications, publicity materials, correspondence on scholarship funding, files on various school activities and projects. There are also reports from research projects conducted at the school. There is some material related to Bryn Mawr students' engagement with the school.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
